thread.title: Arsonists did what the Germans couldn't to this social club - now it is set to be demolished

author: Ian Johnson
title: Arsonists did what the Germans couldn't to this social club - now it is set to be demolished
text:
Firefighters tackle a blaze at the former Swalwell Social Club in 2001 (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
In 2011, arsonists did something even the Germans couldn’t manage.
They burnt Swalwell Social Club in Gateshead to the ground.
During the war, the club defied the Luftwaffe to remain at the heart of the community for decades to come.
But a crippling legal wrangle over the ownership of the club’s land finally proved too much and in 2010 it shut.
A new report has revealed how, since then, the site has deteriorated to the point of ruin. Swalwell and District Social Club in Gateshead (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
“To the south of the building lies overgrown vegetation and two sinkholes,” states Gateshead Council ’s report.
“The club has been subject to fly-tipping, vandalism and arson,”
“The site has been assessed as being situated on ‘potentially contaminated’ land.”
Last year, arsonist struck yet again.
The authority deemed it such an eyesore it gave the green light to turn what was left of the Brewery Bank site to rubble. Read More 'I was homeless as a child in Turkey - now I fear Brexit will stop others from being a success'
The the report adds: “It was agreed with the applicant that no action would be been taken on the basis that a planning application for the demolition and redevelopment of the site was submitted.”
Those plans have now been lodged, with developer Trojan Scaffolding NE Ltd hoping that, from the ashes of the club, can come something good.
It wants to build a dozen two-bedroom flats alongside a pair of semi-detached three-bedroom houses.
The plans have been met with universal positivity, with no objections to date. Read More Hopping mad: Why some people in Jesmond moaned the Hoppings fair 'disrupted their peace'
They are due to go before councillors on May 9, where they are expected to be passed after officers recommended them for approval.
They state the homes would make “a positive contribution to the area”, adding: “[They] would secure the long-term sustainable future.” Like us on Facebook
